articles.headline: Kenneth Chesebro, a Trump-Aligned Lawyer, Pleads Guilty in Georgia
articles.snippet: Mr. Chesebro’s plea deal comes a day after Sidney Powell, another of Donald Trump’s co-defendants in the Georgia election interference case, took a guilty plea.
articles.abstract: Mr. Chesebro’s plea deal comes a day after Sidney Powell, another of Donald Trump’s co-defendants in the Georgia election interference case, took a guilty plea.
articles.lead_paragraph: Kenneth Chesebro on Friday became the second lawyer in two days to plead guilty in a criminal racketeering indictment that also named Donald J. Trump.
articles.byline: By Richard Fausset and Alan Feuer

articles.headline: The Multimillion-Dollar Machines at the Center of the U.S.-China Rivalry
articles.snippet: The United States is taking unusual action to clamp down on sales of chip-making machinery to China, even as Chinese firms are racing to stockpile the equipment.
articles.abstract: The United States is taking unusual action to clamp down on sales of chip-making machinery to China, even as Chinese firms are racing to stockpile the equipment.
articles.lead_paragraph: They are smooth white boxes, roughly the size of large cargo vans, and they are now at the heart of the U.S.-Chinese technology conflict.
articles.byline: By Ana Swanson, Don Clark and Mara Hvistendahl

articles.headline: Passion for Palestinian Cause Had Faded, but Violence in Gaza Reignited It
articles.snippet: The Israeli bombardment of Gaza, in retaliation for a deadly Hamas attack on southern Israel, brought a new outpouring of support in the Arab world for the Palestinian quest for a state.
articles.abstract: The Israeli bombardment of Gaza, in retaliation for a deadly Hamas attack on southern Israel, brought a new outpouring of support in the Arab world for the Palestinian quest for a state.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the Israeli bombardment of Gaza has intensified in recent days, large protests have erupted across the Arab and Muslim worlds in support of the Palestinian cause, a reminder of the profound resonance the issue still holds for many.
articles.byline: By Ben Hubbard

articles.headline: U.S. Deficit, Pegged at $1.7 Trillion, Effectively Doubled in 2023
articles.snippet: The widening gap between what the government spends and what it earns comes as Congress continues to spar over the proper levels of federal spending.
articles.abstract: The widening gap between what the government spends and what it earns comes as Congress continues to spar over the proper levels of federal spending.
articles.lead_paragraph: America’s federal budget deficit effectively doubled in the 2023 fiscal year as slumping tax receipts, rising interest rates and persistent demand for expiring pandemic relief benefits strained the nation’s finances.
articles.byline: By Alan Rappeport and Jim Tankersley

articles.headline: Promised Aid to Gaza Is Stalled by Wrangling, as Conditions Worsen
articles.snippet: Israel, Egypt, the United Nations and others are still working out the details of delivering food, water and medicine, as Israel prepares a possible ground invasion.
articles.abstract: Israel, Egypt, the United Nations and others are still working out the details of delivering food, water and medicine, as Israel prepares a possible ground invasion.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two days after President Biden said he had secured Israel’s agreement to allow food, water and medicine into the besieged Gaza Strip, and a day after aid groups were told their trucks would cross the border on Friday, nothing budged, as the powers involved continued to haggle over the details, while conditions within Gaza grew more dire.
articles.byline: By Vivian Yee and Matina Stevis-Gridneff

articles.headline: Biden and Aides Advise Israel to Avoid Widening War With Hezbollah Strike
articles.snippet: U.S. officials learned that the Israeli defense minister and other military officials supported a pre-emptive strike on Hezbollah. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has been cautious.
articles.abstract: U.S. officials learned that the Israeli defense minister and other military officials supported a pre-emptive strike on Hezbollah. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has been cautious.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Biden and his top aides have been urging Israeli leaders against carrying out any major strike against Hezbollah, the powerful militia in Lebanon, that could draw it into the Israel-Hamas war, American and Israeli officials say.
articles.byline: By Edward Wong, Ronen Bergman and Julian E. Barnes

articles.headline: How Ron DeSantis Lost the Internet
articles.snippet: The G.O.P. contender’s campaign tried to take on Donald Trump’s online army. Now it just wants to end the meme wars.
articles.abstract: The G.O.P. contender’s campaign tried to take on Donald Trump’s online army. Now it just wants to end the meme wars.
articles.lead_paragraph: In early May, as Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida prepared to run for president, about a dozen right-wing social media influencers gathered at his pollster’s home for cocktails and a poolside buffet.
articles.byline: By Ken Bensinger and Nicholas Nehamas

articles.headline: How Rich Donors and Loose Rules Are Transforming College Sports
articles.snippet: A shift that allows booster groups to employ student-athletes has upended the economics of college football and other sports while giving many donors a tax break.
articles.abstract: A shift that allows booster groups to employ student-athletes has upended the economics of college football and other sports while giving many donors a tax break.
articles.lead_paragraph: The key to recruiting top college football players these days is not just a lavish training facility or a storied coach. It is ensuring the chance for them to hook up with a new type of operation that can pay them eye-popping sums, collected from wealthy boosters who can often write off the donations, for taking on a bit of outside work.
articles.byline: By David A. Fahrenthold and Billy Witz

articles.headline: It’s Not Just for Throuples Anymore
articles.snippet: Feeld, the kink- and queer-friendly dating app, has carved out a niche for customers looking for something unusual in potential romantic partners — honesty.
articles.abstract: Feeld, the kink- and queer-friendly dating app, has carved out a niche for customers looking for something unusual in potential romantic partners — honesty.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Ana Kirova first heard the idea that she should become chief executive of Feeld, the dating app, she was “terrified.”
articles.byline: By Valeriya Safronova

articles.headline: First Humanitarian Aid Reaches a Hard-Pressed Gaza
articles.snippet: But the 20-truck shipment of food, water and medical supplies is only a fraction of what is needed to head off a catastrophe, officials say.
articles.abstract: But the 20-truck shipment of food, water and medical supplies is only a fraction of what is needed to head off a catastrophe, officials say.
articles.lead_paragraph: After days of diplomatic wrangling, 20 trucks carrying food, water and medical supplies crossed into Gaza on Saturday, providing a ray of hope for the more than two million residents of the enclave, whose living conditions the United Nations called “catastrophic.”
articles.byline: By Thomas Fuller and Vivian Yee

articles.headline: Why Olive Oil Is So Expensive Right Now
articles.snippet: Prices have more than doubled as extreme weather hit crops in Spain, Italy and elsewhere. The upcoming harvest isn’t looking much better, so that drizzle of oil on your salad may remain costly.
articles.abstract: Prices have more than doubled as extreme weather hit crops in Spain, Italy and elsewhere. The upcoming harvest isn’t looking much better, so that drizzle of oil on your salad may remain costly.
articles.lead_paragraph: There is something different lately about the olive oil Michelle Spangler buys, bottles and infuses with flavors like basil and blood orange for her store in Dallas. It’s not the taste but the cost: Global olive oil prices have soared to record levels, more than doubling over the past year.
articles.byline: By Santul Nerkar

articles.headline: The Race to Save Our Secrets From the Computers of the Future
articles.snippet: Quantum technology could compromise our encryption systems. Can America replace them before it’s too late?
articles.abstract: Quantum technology could compromise our encryption systems. Can America replace them before it’s too late?
articles.lead_paragraph: They call it Q-Day: the day when a quantum computer, one more powerful than any yet built, could shatter the world of privacy and security as we know it.
articles.byline: By Zach Montague

articles.headline: Peace, a Forgotten Word, Renews its Claim in the Holy Land
articles.snippet: Long derided as naïve, even traitors, the bridge builders between Israelis and Palestinians sense opportunity in the aftermath of the Hamas attack.
articles.abstract: Long derided as naïve, even traitors, the bridge builders between Israelis and Palestinians sense opportunity in the aftermath of the Hamas attack.
articles.lead_paragraph: Awad Darawshe, shot in the abdomen, bled to death under the stage at the trance music festival that Hamas gunmen transformed into a killing field. A Palestinian Israeli paramedic, he died in a desperate attempt to save the lives of Jews at the Tribe of Nova peace-and-love gathering that marked the Jewish holiday of Sukkot.
articles.byline: By Roger Cohen

articles.headline: A President, a Billionaire and Questions About Access and National Security
articles.snippet: Anthony Pratt, one of Australia’s wealthiest men, made his way into Donald Trump’s inner circle with money and flattery. What he heard there has become of interest to federal prosecutors.
articles.abstract: Anthony Pratt, one of Australia’s wealthiest men, made his way into Donald Trump’s inner circle with money and flattery. What he heard there has become of interest to federal prosecutors.
articles.lead_paragraph: The 2020 presidential campaign was underway, and Anthony Pratt was doubling down on Donald J. Trump.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess, Jonathan Swan, Maggie Haberman and Alan Feuer

articles.headline: Israelis and Gazans Flee Amid Clashes and Warnings of Wider Regional War
articles.snippet: Violence on Israel’s northern border with Lebanon, and strikes in Syria and the West Bank, sent shock waves through the Middle East.
articles.abstract: Violence on Israel’s northern border with Lebanon, and strikes in Syria and the West Bank, sent shock waves through the Middle East.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Israeli forces massed along the border with Gaza on Sunday ahead of an expected ground invasion, escalating clashes on Israel’s northern border with Lebanon, as well as strikes in Syria and in the Israeli-occupied West Bank, intensified fears of a widening regional conflict.
articles.byline: By Isabel Kershner, Raja Abdulrahim, Euan Ward and Michael Levenson

articles.headline: Hamas Fails to Make Case That Israel Struck Hospital
articles.snippet: A senior Hamas official says “nothing is left” of the munition that hit the Ahli Arab hospital in Gaza City last week, killing hundreds. Israel says the explosion was caused by a misfired Palestinian rocket.
articles.abstract: A senior Hamas official says “nothing is left” of the munition that hit the Ahli Arab hospital in Gaza City last week, killing hundreds. Israel says the explosion was caused by a misfired Palestinian rocket.
articles.lead_paragraph: Six days after Hamas accused Israel of bombing a hospital in Gaza City and killing hundreds of people, the armed Palestinian group has yet to produce or describe any evidence linking Israel to the strike, says it cannot find the munition that hit the site and has declined to provide detail to support its count of the casualties.
articles.byline: By Patrick Kingsley and Aaron Boxerman

articles.headline: How High Interest Rates Sting Bakers, Farmers and Consumers
articles.snippet: Everyone who relies on credit in America is confronting a new reality: Money will cost more for a good long while.
articles.abstract: Everyone who relies on credit in America is confronting a new reality: Money will cost more for a good long while.
articles.lead_paragraph: Home buyers, entrepreneurs and public officials are confronting a new reality: If they want to hold off on big purchases or investments until borrowing is less expensive, it’s probably going to be a long wait.
articles.byline: By Lydia DePillis

articles.headline: Kill and Be Killed: Ukraine’s Bloody Battlefield Equation
articles.snippet: The dynamics of Europe’s deadliest war in generations remain exceedingly violent and increasingly complicated by factors far from the battlefield.
articles.abstract: The dynamics of Europe’s deadliest war in generations remain exceedingly violent and increasingly complicated by factors far from the battlefield.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Russia mounted wave after wave of attacks over the summer, Sgt. Mykola Rogozovets and fellow members of his unit started drawing little plus signs in the dirt of their bunker while artillery shook the ground around them.
articles.byline: By Marc Santora and Constant Méheut

articles.headline: Chevron to Acquire Hess for $53 Billion in Latest Major Oil Deal
articles.snippet: The acquisition marks further consolidation of the oil industry and highlights the confidence that energy companies have in the future of fossil fuels.
articles.abstract: The acquisition marks further consolidation of the oil industry and highlights the confidence that energy companies have in the future of fossil fuels.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the second energy megadeal this month, Chevron, the second-largest U.S. oil giant, said Monday that it had agreed to acquire Hess, a medium-size rival, in an all-stock deal valued at $53 billion.
articles.byline: By Clifford Krauss and Stanley Reed

articles.headline: Nonunion Workers Are Playing a Big Role in the Autoworkers’ Strike
articles.snippet: The three U.S. automakers say they are already at a disadvantage to nonunion rivals while labor leaders hope that big gains in negotiations will inspire workers in Southern states to unionize.
articles.abstract: The three U.S. automakers say they are already at a disadvantage to nonunion rivals while labor leaders hope that big gains in negotiations will inspire workers in Southern states to unionize.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tens of thousands of people who work for Toyota in Kentucky, Mercedes-Benz in Alabama or Tesla in Texas are technically not involved in the high-stakes negotiations taking place between labor and management in and around Detroit.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing

articles.headline: U.A.W. Expands Strike to a Ram Plant in Michigan
articles.snippet: The United Automobile Workers union called on 6,800 workers to walk off the job at a large factory that makes one of Stellantis’s most profitable vehicles.
articles.abstract: The United Automobile Workers union called on 6,800 workers to walk off the job at a large factory that makes one of Stellantis’s most profitable vehicles.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a major escalation of its six-week strike at the three large U.S. automakers, the United Automobile Workers union on Monday told 6,800 workers at a large Ram pickup truck plant in Michigan to walk off the job.
articles.byline: By Neal E. Boudette

articles.headline: The Stratospheric Rise of Lionel Messi’s Pink Jersey
articles.snippet: In the span of three months, the soccer superstar has made Inter Miami’s eye-catching jersey the hottest piece of sports merchandise on the planet.
articles.abstract: In the span of three months, the soccer superstar has made Inter Miami’s eye-catching jersey the hottest piece of sports merchandise on the planet.
articles.lead_paragraph: All of a sudden, after a single summer, the pink jersey is everywhere. It has become almost impossible to acquire, yet there it is, paradoxically, on the backs of thousands of fans thronging American stadiums, hanging from market stalls in Buenos Aires and Bangkok, a vivid flash on almost every field where children gather to play soccer in England.
articles.byline: By Kevin Draper and Rory Smith
